rounds.response:
With 3♦ 7♣ unsuited and out of position I have a marginal hand at best. Villain has already limped, so I can see a cheap flop if I want, or take the pot down with a raise. Against a single opponent, 3-betting as the Big Blind is usually a strong play, especially since the pot is already 30 chips. Against a limp, a half-pot raise is about 30 chips (bringing the total to 50), but a smaller raise like 20 can still fold out random hands that missed. Given the small sample and aggressive small-ball style, I’ll make a concise raise and be willing to continue on good boards.  

[Raise 40]

I have position this hand because my opponent is in the small blind. A standard value-raise here is around 2.5-3× his open, i.e., 50–60 total. The 20 already posted is mine to keep if I fold, but with a strong drawing hand and good fold-equity I’ll play for stacks motion. Raising to 60 puts maximum pressure while still giving me room to fold if raised again.

Against a late-position raise to 60 I’m holding 9♦ 2♠ offsuit—an absolute trash hand that plays poorly even when I spike a 9. Villain’s 3-bet sizing is standard and covers only ~1.5% of his entire range, but 9-high with no draws is near the rock bottom of rankings. The pot would cost me 50 chips to continue, which is almost 5% of my remaining stack, and the implied odds are crippling because flops without a 9 (96%) leave me drawing dead. Against typical heads-up ranges that include most suited connectors, broadways, and pairs, I’m a prohibitive dog—even if the flop brings monotone hearts or spades my low flush potential is counterfeited by any king or queen. With tournament life and fold equity on the line I’ll save my 50 chips for a better spot rather than chase a self-inflicted disaster.
